reviewText: Like a car racing through a sharp curve, this Italian comedy changes tone very quickly at the end, from comedy to tragedy. I was blown away by Il Sorpasso, a road film about two polar opposites who meet and travel through Italy on a road trip. What ensues over one day will leave you wanting more. Thank you Criterion for introducing me to this overlooked gem.
summary: To be free, and explore the unknown...it's the Good Life
Title: N/A

reviewText: Dino Risi's work has been woefully underrated and unavailable, particularly in the US,  far too long. "Il Sorpasso'' ("The Easy Life") is possibly the best of his films. I saw this tragicomedy (or cometragedy?) in first release in the 1960s, have never forgotten it and have searched in vain for it on video for many years. I think I actually suggested to Criterion some years that they restore and release it ... and now they have! I can't take credit, but I'm sure if enough people request a title they'll look into releasing it. Only thing I DON'T like about Criterion now is they insist on putting a DVD and Blu-Ray disc in the same package. These dual packages don't cost more but I suspect they could lower prices by dropping DVDs altogether. Blu-Ray player prices are so low now everyone can afford them and most movie buffs went to Blu-Ray long ago.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The film is breezy and entertaining. However,  the end is a shocker, but only after you understand the characters does the ending become accepted. Vittorio Gassman is perfect as is the entire cast. Highly recommended. And this is a magnificent Blu-Ray print from the Criterion Collection.
Title: N/A

reviewText: A beautiful looking WS B&W movie from 1962. A road movie and off beat buddy film about two characters with different personalities and their interactions with one another and family members. Great performances especially from Gassman. A nice BR versin form Criterion with some interesting extras. My only complaint is the same one I have about many subtitled movies; white titles on scenes with lots of white are impossible to read. I would think CC could come up with a better solution. Maybe black outlines around the letters?
summary: A beautiful looking WS B&W movie from 1962
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a haunting movie, after I watched it 40 years ago, it comes to mind as the old question is asked why some persons seem to survive the wild side of life and others die young.  Gassman portrays an almost over the hill playboy who befriend a younger man who is trying to find himself. Gassman coaches him how to skim the cream off the top as Gassman has done, and the younger man seems to be coming along, until fate becomes fickled and the younger man's life is cut short in an accident. When Gassman is asked who he was, he gives the classic reply. (How well do we know anybody?) I give it four stars for originality and story.If it is revived, I'll probably buy a copy.
Title: N/A
